Wez

Just a thought I had reading another thread.
 
 What do you think of taking children on a school trip to a prison (preferably one of the 'worse' ones) at a fairly young age to scare them of prison? Has this been done? Would it/does it work?
 
 -Wez
jim's trucking

Just a thought I had reading another thread.
 
 What do you think of taking children on a school trip to a prison (preferably one of the 'worse' ones) at a fairly young age to scare them of prison? Has this been done? Would it/does it work?
 
 -Wez
I advocate building the schools right across the street from the prisons. The prisoners could serve as night time janitors in the schools. The schools could organize field trips to visit the prisons and study the lifestyle. This would likely keep a lot of kids out of prison.
Symbiote

Why not instead intern youth on a 6-hourly daily basis in a place that resembles a prison - barbed wire fencing, sniffer dogs, metal detectors, a regimented timetable, drugdealers, stabbings, drab environments, announcements over PA systems, poor quality food dispensed onto trays, eaten on metal benches, public servants ordering them around, telling them how to think and behave, a rudimentary barter economy.
 
 I think, if you took students to tour a prison, they would find it very similar to the environment they experience on a daily basis. Sure, they might be "scared" because the bullies are a little meaner, but only in the same way primary school students are "scared" of secondary school - once they are old enough they'll be ready to take that step.
sinjin

Couldn't we wait until the kids that seem predisposed to crime show themselves. I should hope most kids will want to be law abiding not simply for fear of prison but because it's the better way. Field trips to cool places of employment for convicts might be a better tool for reducing criminal behavior. I 've heard of a few jailbirds that were encouraged to go straight in part as a consequence to the firefighting they did while incarcerated.
Voice Of Reason
I think it pretty much depends on the age of the students you take...........I would say it would be a good idea for children when they reach the age of about 13.
Tastyfish

Unless you want to put anal rape onto the curriculum and have the students study the cycle of abuses and how to smuggle drugs - surely its going to just be dull, with a lot of people in small rooms. 
 How about have the biggest and meanest of the criminals take some of the kids into the shower and have his way with them - now that would sort them out good and proper. Unless they are gay of course but at least you then know the ones to segregate from the class so it doesn't spread.
georged

I toured the local jail as a kid, Boy Scout field trip. Looked pretty mean to me, the prisoners looked sleazy and it left a lasting impression. That was so long ago interior decoration wasn't high on the requirement list, starch for calories was the food criterion and visual occupation such as TV to reduce guard requirements was still way in the future. I immediately knew the wrong side of the bars wasn't some place I ever wanted to be located.
 
 Contemporary kids are exposed to so much TV violence from the formative years on that I don't think a modern jail or prison would have much shock or deterrent value. Little rooms painted in the latest psychobabble colors, people glued to watching TV and some screaming would probably make many of them feel right at home. They might even run into daddy. 
 
 Our social ills are far too advanced and widespread for deterrents to have any effect on many kids choosing between crime and becoming contributing members of society. The best job going for a high school grad without the desire to continue education is now the military, where an automatic weapon and the chance to be killed in our humanitarian spread of democracy are a good probability. We set great examples.
Tastyfish

More importantly I think the number of criminals who actually weigh up the odds of going to prison are quite low, most just don't think they will get caught - no deterrant like this is going to be able to deal with these, really.
georged

More importantly I think the number of criminals who actually weigh up the odds of going to prison are quite low, most just don't think they will get caught - no deterrant like this is going to be able to deal with these, really.

 
 Unless they commit a high profile crime, or join the drug ranks where most federal LE funding grants are directed, their odds of not going to prison are excellent. With the highest per-capita prison population in the developed world, we can't build prisons fast enough to service our justice system. I don't remember the exact statistic on this, and will stand corrected with a source, but something like 90% of criminal cases are plea-bargained away to probation and/or community service. The charity kitchen I'm associated with has a non-stop supply of grunt labor from people doing community service. Our highways are immaculate from community service in lieu of jail. Kids from those families and peer families don't notice those things? I don't think getting caught is their primary concern, they know the system and punishment better than someone without that intent.
daewoo

With the highest per-capita prison population in the developed world, we can't build prisons fast enough to service our justice system. Kids from those families and peer families don't notice those things? I don't think getting caught is their primary concern, they know the system and punishment better than someone without that intent.

 
 90% plea bargained away, and only 1 in 5 ever captured anyway, and we STILL can't build the jails fast enough.
jitobear
I actually know woman who took her kids to the local juvenile detention center and that was enough to scare them....
Voice Of Reason

I actually know woman who took her kids to the local juvenile detention center and that was enough to scare them....

 
 Visiting a juvenile detention center would be a good step but I think visiting a maximum security prison would be much more effective..........
jim's trucking

Visiting a juvenile detention center would be a good step but I think visiting a maximum security prison would be much more effective..........
Yes. Maybe each student shold be required to spend 24 hrs in one...as a prisoner.
Tastyfish

Surely relying on the stereotpyed prison of films and TV is going to be more effective - you aren't going to be able to show the real downsides to prison life in just a day (that is kind of the point) but over years, and the stigma you get when you come out. Just showing them the prison for a day isn't going to scare people, its nothing compared to the rumours they hear and can imagine. Prison for a day is just tatooed guys in a small room. Be more scared in a lot of bars on a weekend.
jim's trucking
Maybe we could make a year in prison count as your junior year. Let everyone skip eleventh grade and spend a year behind bars. emoticon_xclown

From what we see in most public schools - could certainly save court time and costs as well ;)
georged

Maybe we could make a year in prison count as your junior year. Let everyone skip eleventh grade and spend a year behind bars. emoticon_xclown

 
 Too late. Especially considering juvenile detention is often referred to as granting the equivalent of a college degree in crime to budding criminals. A year in the slam at that age would produce doctorals in crime.

 That is true and some ol fashioned corporal punishment in our public schools might help too........

I do have to say you certainly are a gaggle of grumpy old men here. This generation of rats has got its bad seeds for sure, but for the most part they are a pretty groovy bunch. :p 
 
 I don't know that there are more rotten people than before - just better technology, organizations, efficency and methods in crime.
daewoo

Yes. Maybe each student shold be required to spend 24 hrs in one...as a prisoner.

 
 This may be going a little far. I do think that judges should be required to spend a few days behind bars. If they are going to be handing out prison sentences and jail time, they need to know where they are sending folks.
georged

I do have to say you certainly are a gaggle of grumpy old men here. This generation of rats has got its bad seeds for sure, but for the most part they are a pretty groovy bunch. :p 
 
 I don't know that there are more rotten people than before - just better technology, organizations, efficency and methods in crime.

 
 The older a gaggle of men becomes, the rule of thumb is they increase their personal, material wealth at a corresponding rate. The more one has to lose, the higher the risk factor of have-nots desiring redistribution by any means. Personal wealth levels and standards of living at the worker class have been and are deteriorating due to stagnated wages and loss of purchasing power. Grumpy old men like myself dislike the thought of expanding our exposure through poor education creating more have-nots and a jammed up judicial system letting convicted criminals walk because the prisons are full. 
 
 Something's not right when the wealthest nation in the world has the highest per-capita prison population in the developed world and 90% of all convictions are plea-bargained because the prisons are full.
daewoo

Something's not right when the wealthiest nation in the world has the highest per-capita prison population in the developed world and 90% of all convictions are plea-bargained because the prisons are full.

 
 Not everybody is happy with the two tiered society we are hatching here.

 And they always find someone else to blame for their mistakes, just like the standing administration. We're discussing school trips to prison as a crime deterrent. How desperate does it have to get?
